output.conclusion: Upon completion of this advanced Engineering Mechanics course, participants will possess a comprehensive understanding of complex mechanical systems and be equipped to tackle challenging engineering problems with confidence and precision.
output.courseTitle: Engineering Mechanics: Advanced Principles and Applications
output.introduction: This course delves into advanced concepts in Engineering Mechanics, building upon foundational knowledge to explore complex systems and problem-solving techniques. Designed for experienced engineers and researchers, it provides a rigorous treatment of topics essential for advanced analysis and design.

chapters.chapterTitle: Tensor Analysis for Stress and Strain
chapters.description: Review of tensor notation; stress and strain tensors; transformation laws; principal stresses and strains; invariants; applications to anisotropic materials.
Hyperelastic material models; viscoplasticity; creep; damage mechanics; introduction to finite element formulation based on advanced material models.
Principle of virtual work; principle of minimum potential energy; Castigliano's theorems; applications to complex structural systems.
Buckling of columns and beams; energy methods for stability analysis; dynamic stability; introduction to post-buckling behavior.
Euler angles; angular momentum; kinetic energy; Euler's equations of motion; gyroscopic motion; applications to spacecraft and robotics.
Wave equation; free and forced vibrations of strings, rods, and beams; modal analysis; damping; applications to structural dynamics.
Navier-Stokes equations; boundary layer theory; turbulence modeling; computational fluid dynamics (CFD) fundamentals.
Added mass; aeroelasticity; hydroelasticity; applications to aerospace and marine engineering.
Stress intensity factors; fracture criteria; fatigue crack growth; applications to structural integrity assessment.
Micromechanics and macromechanics of composites; lamination theory; failure analysis; applications to aerospace and automotive industries.
